failure_analysis: All previous attempts fell short because they failed to address the core inefficiency: the correlated subquery performs a per-row re-evaluation of an aggregate against the same base table (web_sales) with similar filtering conditions. The implicit comma-join syntax hides join ordering opportunities, and attempts to pre-filter dimensions didn't eliminate the fundamental performance penalty of repeated subquery execution. Materialization attempts likely suffered from suboptimal join orders or missed the chance to compute the subquery aggregate once per item.

refined_strategy: Use a CTE to precompute per-item average discount amounts with all subquery conditions, then join this with the main query using explicit JOIN syntax. This eliminates correlation overhead by computing the threshold once per item. Additionally, pre-filter date_dim and web_sales in separate CTEs with explicit joins to ensure optimal join ordering and predicate pushdown.
